title: Coloring A Border
question_content:
You are given an m x n integer matrix grid, and three integers row, col, and color. Each value in the grid represents the color of the grid square at that location.
Two squares are called adjacent if they are next to each other in any of the 4 directions.
Two squares belong to the same connected component if they have the same color and they are adjacent.
The border of a connected component is all the squares in the connected component that are either adjacent to (at least) a square not in the component, or on the boundary of the grid (the first or last row or column).
You should color the border of the connected component that contains the square grid[row][col] with color.
Return the final grid.
 
Example 1:
Input: grid = [[1,1],[1,2]], row = 0, col = 0, color = 3
Output: [[3,3],[3,2]]
Example 2:
Input: grid = [[1,2,2],[2,3,2]], row = 0, col = 1, color = 3
Output: [[1,3,3],[2,3,3]]
Example 3:
Input: grid = [[1,1,1],[1,1,1],[1,1,1]], row = 1, col = 1, color = 2
Output: [[2,2,2],[2,1,2],[2,2,2]]
 
Constraints:

	m == grid.length
	n == grid[i].length
	1 <= m, n <= 50
	1 <= grid[i][j], color <= 1000
	0 <= row < m
	0 <= col < n

solutions.content:
consider the 2nd example: ```grid = [[1,2,2],[2,3,2]], r0 = 0, c0 = 1, color = 3```
the grid would look like this:
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/b81e1f42-f919-4a54-9507-9ff6077c2e25_1597042429.4147203.png)
Now, the given location is ``` r0 = 0, c0 = 1``` which is the 2nd cell in first row. So, the component would be:
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/4a571c93-2af4-4f7f-8768-363158557ab9_1597042643.770675.png)
Now, coming to the color changing part
**change the color of the cell at ```(0, 1)```** because  by the definition of the border
```The border of a connected component is all the squares in the connected component that are 4-directionally adjacent to a square not in the component```
1.  it is part of the component
2.  it is 4-directionally adjacent to a square not in the component (below it there a cell with color 3, and on the left there is cell with color 1, so, it meets the criteria)
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/796bde1c-f034-40f1-a463-8b3421543db5_1597045011.3280766.png)


Now, **change the color of the cell at ```(0, 2)```**.
It is not 4-directionally adjacent to a square not in the component (it does not have neighbour whose color is different from itself) **but it is on the border of the grid** (i.e., the first or last row or column of the grid). So, we have to change its color.
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/f3449341-bf34-4ef5-b30d-d54e0d838a39_1597045067.3039854.png)

Now, coming to last cell of our component ```(1,2)```, it follows both the criteria
1. it is on the border
2. it has a neighbour which does not belong to the component and different from itself.
So, we have to change its color.
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/6ec7d7f8-3fd3-49bf-819e-9ee13a64c31d_1597045304.0051892.png)

Therefore, the output is: ```[[1, 3, 3], [2, 3, 3]]```
**Why didnt we change the color of cell at ```(1,0)```?**
it follows both the criteria, but **it doesnt belong to the component**
This is my understanding of the problem. I stuggled quite a bit to understand the problem statement and I just want to make it simple to understand for others too.
correct me if I did mistake.

detailed-explanation-with-pictures
solutions.content:
` Suppose given `
![paint1.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/81a9c04e-3300-4a5b-aec8-23d2d6fd965d_1687797247.1981645.png)

``` 
All the neighbour(4 directions) of grid[1][3] including neighbours of the neighbours of 
grid[1][3]
```
![paint1.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/d6939f0f-dce2-4b2b-b292-e4f49b5e8ef0_1687797844.4885716.png)

```
Now you have to go through the all of those grid[1][3]'s neighbours and change the color of 
those cells which are on the border(cell whose 4 direction cells values are not equal to
 that cell value)
```
```
Let's look at the cell grid[1][2].
```
![mainnnnnn.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/06cc3008-5f1c-4c29-bfc1-e346b3f523fc_1687799040.5686803.png)

```
Here only the upper neighbour(green marked) is not same as grid[1][2] (purple marked).
So grid[1][2] is on the border and thus we color it to 1.
```
```
For grid[1][1] : 
```
![main2.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/d6da1151-583a-4811-968a-a1bd0bbf4aa5_1687799443.3790708.png)

```
For grid[1][1](purple marked) all it's neighbour has the same value as grid[1][1] has, means
this cell is not on the border and that's why we won't color it to 1.
```
```
Final Output : (red = previous color, blue = new color)
```
![soll.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/f6b3551f-c996-4945-bbb8-348d2fe8ed1d_1687800180.4796717.png)


### My Solution Explanation :
```
If you want to run the dfs and change the border cell to new color in the dfs it would
be huge messy : 
```
![leo.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/880985b8-14b1-4027-bb6a-04631a3d1743_1687804434.6937025.png)

```
If I change the color of grid[1][3] and grid[1][2] at the same time in dfs function, then 
for grid[1][1] (purple marked) it's right neighbour(grid[1][2]) is 1 and grid[1][1] will be 
colored to 1 as it's all neighbours value are not same as grid[1][1] BUT grid[1][1] can't be
colored to 1 as in the Q it's all neighbour has the same value as its.
```
```
Instead I made a boolean array of the same size as grid and marked all the neighbours of 
grid[row][col] as 1 in dfs(). Now I can easily traverse the 'visited' array and change the 
border cells of 'grid' to 'color'.
```
![OPP.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/c52babc0-2983-4496-860b-21f4ac018440_1687806180.8875253.png)

```
To check if the current cell (grid[r][c]) is on the border or not :

1. If the cell is on the first or the last row as 'CELLS ON THE FIRST ROW MISSING UPPER 
   NEIGHBOUR' AND 'LAST ROW BOTTOM NEIGHBOUR'.
2. If the cell is on the first colomn(missing left neighbour) or the last colomn(missing right 
   neighbour)
3. If the cell in the middle, then check if all the neighbour has 1 in the 'visited' array, 
   because if one of them is 0 means it's a border cell. 

   NO NEED TO CHECK IF THE CELL (WHOSE NEIGHBOURS HAS 1 OR NOT) HAS ALSO 1 BECAUSE UNLESS THAT 
   CELL HAD NOT 1 WE WOULDN'T BE CHECKING IF ALL ITS NEIGHBOURS AS 1 OR NOT.    
```

```CPP []
class Solution 
{
public:
    vector<vector<int>> diff = {{0, -1}, {-1, 0}, {0, 1}, {1, 0}}; // left up right down
    
    bool on_border_or_neighbours_not_equal(vector<vector<bool>>& visited, int r, int c){
        if(r == 0 || r == visited.size()-1 || c == 0 || c == visited[0].size()-1) // on border conditions
            return true;
        int left = visited[r][c-1], up = visited[r-1][c], right = visited[r][c+1], down = visited[r+1][c];
        return left != 1 || up != 1 || right != 1 || down != 1; // at least one neighbour is different conditions
    }
    
    void create_border(vector<vector<int>>& grid, vector<vector<bool>> &visited, int newcolor)
    {
        for(int r=0; r<visited.size(); r++)
        {
            for(int c=0; c<visited[0].size(); c++)
                if(visited[r][c] == 1 && on_border_or_neighbours_not_equal(visited, r, c))
                    grid[r][c] = newcolor;
        }
    }

    void dfs(vector<vector<int>>& grid, int r, int c, int oldcolor, vector<vector<bool>> &visited)
    {
        if(r<0 || r>=grid.size() || c<0 || c>=grid[0].size() || visited[r][c] == 1 || grid[r][c] != oldcolor)
            return;
        visited[r][c] = 1;
        for(const auto &d : diff)
            dfs(grid, r+d[0], c+d[1], oldcolor, visited);
    }

    vector<vector<int>> colorBorder(vector<vector<int>>& grid, int row, int col, int color)
    {
        vector<vector<bool>> visited(grid.size(), vector<bool>(grid[0].size()));
        dfs(grid, row, col, grid[row][col], visited);
        create_border(grid, visited, color);
        return grid;
    }
};
```
```Python []
class Solution:
    def colorBorder(self, grid: List[List[int]], row: int, col: int, color: int) -> List[List[int]]:
        ROW, COL, oldcolor = len(grid), len(grid[0]), grid[row][col]
        visited = [ [0 for _ in range(COL)] for _ in range(ROW) ]

        def dfs(r:int, c:int):
            if r<0 or r>=ROW or c<0 or c>=COL or visited[r][c] == 1 or grid[r][c] != oldcolor :
                return
            visited[r][c] = 1
            [ dfs(r+x, c+y) for (x,y) in ((0, -1), (-1, 0), (0, 1), (1, 0)) ]
        
        def on_border_or_neighbours_not_equal(r:int, c:int) -> bool:
            if r == 0 or r == ROW-1 or c == 0 or c == COL-1 : # on border
                return True
            left, up, right, down = visited[r][c-1], visited[r-1][c], visited[r][c+1], visited[r+1][c]
            return left != 1 or up != 1 or right != 1 or down != 1 # min 1 neighbour is different or not
        
        def create_border():
            for r in range(ROW):
                for c in range(COL):
                    if visited[r][c] == 1 and on_border_or_neighbours_not_equal(r, c):
                        grid[r][c] = color

        dfs(row, col)
        create_border()
        return grid
```
```
Time  complexity : O(m*n)
Space complexity : O(m*n)
```
### It took me plenty time to explain everything. If the post was useful to you, an upvote will really make me happy. Thank you for reading it till the end.

solutions.content:
```
class Solution:
    def colorBorder(self, grid: List[List[int]], r0: int, c0: int, color: int) -> List[List[int]]:
        
        def dfs(r, c, current, border, seen):
            
            # if out of range or seen
            if r<0 or c<0 or r >= len(grid) or c >= len(grid[0]) or grid[r][c] != current or (r,c) in seen:
                return
            
            seen.add((r,c))
            
            # if it is a border
            if (r==0 or c==0 or r==len(grid)-1 or c==len(grid[0])-1 or grid[r-1][c] != current or grid[r+1][c] != current or grid[r][c-1] != current or grid[r][c+1] != current):
                border.add((r,c))
                
                
            dfs(r-1, c, current, border, seen)
            dfs(r+1, c, current, border, seen)
            dfs(r, c-1, current, border, seen)
            dfs(r, c+1, current, border, seen)
                
            return
        
        if not grid:
            return grid
        
        current = grid[r0][c0]
        border = set()
        seen = set()
        dfs(r0, c0, current, border, seen)
        
        for elem in border:
            grid[elem[0]][elem[1]] = color
        
        return grid
```

dfs-intuitive-with-is-valid-pixel-and-is-border-helpers
solutions.content:
# Intuition
At first glance, the problem requires us to change the color of the border of a region in an image. Since the region is defined as all pixels with the same color that are 4-directionally connected (meaning they are connected either vertically or horizontally), the natural inclination is to solve this problem using depth-first search (DFS), a well-known algorithm used for traversing or searching tree or graph data structures. We use DFS to visit all pixels in the region. While doing this, we also check if the current pixel is on the border of the region, and if so, we color it with the new color.

# Approach
The approach to solve this problem involves three helper functions: `is_valid_pixel`, `is_border`, and `dfs`. `is_valid_pixel` checks if a pixel is inside the image and if it has the original color. `is_border` checks if a pixel is on the border of the image or is adjacent to a pixel that is not part of the region and has not yet been visited. If a pixel satisfies these conditions, it's a border pixel.

The `dfs` function is where we perform the depth-first search. It checks if the current pixel is valid and unvisited. If it is a border pixel, we change its color to the new color. We then visit all four directions from the current pixel.

Finally, the condition `original_color != newColor` prevents infinite loops when the new color is the same as the original color.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: The time complexity of this solution is O(n), where n is the number of pixels in the image. In the worst-case scenario, every pixel in the image is visited once.
  
- Space complexity: The space complexity is also O(n), where n is the number of pixels in the image. The space complexity comes from the memory used to store the visited set and the memory used for the stack in the recursive DFS function. In the worst-case scenario, the depth of recursion could go up to n. This worst-case scenario would occur if all pixels have the same color and the starting pixel is at one corner of the image.

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def colorBorder(self, image: List[List[int]], sr: int, sc: int, newColor: int) -> List[List[int]]:
        DIRECTIONS = [(0, 1), (0, -1), (-1, 0), (1, 0)]
        R = len(image); C = len(image[0])
        original_color = image[sr][sc]
        visited = set()

        # return true if the pixel is in the image
        def is_valid_pixel(row, col):
            return 0 <= row < R and 0 <= col < C and image[row][col] == original_color

        # return True if the pixel is at the border
        def is_border(row, col):
            return row == 0 or row == R-1 or col == 0 or col == C-1 or any(
                0 <= row + dr < R and 0 <= col + dc < C and image[row + dr][col + dc] != original_color and (row+dr, col+dc) not in visited
                for dr, dc in DIRECTIONS
            )

        def dfs(row, col):
            if not is_valid_pixel(row, col) or (row, col) in visited:
                return
            if is_border(row, col):
                image[row][col] = newColor
            visited.add((row, col))
            for dr, dc in DIRECTIONS:
                dfs(row + dr, col + dc)

        if original_color != newColor:
            dfs(sr, sc)
        return image

```

# is_border
`is_border` determines whether a given pixel, specified by its row and column indices, is on the border of a region with the same color in the image.

Here is a detailed explanation of the logic:

- `row == 0 or row == R-1 or col == 0 or col == C-1`: This condition checks if the pixel is on the edge of the image. If it is, it's part of the border by definition.

- `any(0 <= row + dr < R and 0 <= col + dc < C and image[row + dr][col + dc] != original_color and (row+dr, col+dc) not in visited for dr, dc in DIRECTIONS)`: This condition uses the `any` function, which returns `True` if any element in the iterable it's given is `True`. It's iterating over the four possible directions from the current pixel (up, down, left, right) represented by `DIRECTIONS`.

  - `0 <= row + dr < R and 0 <= col + dc < C`: These conditions check that the pixel in the direction `(dr, dc)` is still within the image bounds.

  - `image[row + dr][col + dc] != original_color`: This condition checks that the color of the pixel in the direction `(dr, dc)` is different from the original color. This would mean that the current pixel is next to a pixel of a different color, and is therefore on the border of its region.

  - `(row+dr, col+dc) not in visited`: This condition checks that the pixel in the direction `(dr, dc)` has not been visited. This is to ensure that we don't count pixels that have already been recolored as being different, as they might have been the same color originally. 
If any of these conditions is `True`, the function will return `True`, indicating that the pixel is indeed a border pixel.

```
class Solution:
    def colorBorder(self, grid: List[List[int]], row: int, col: int, color: int) -> List[List[int]]:
        
        
        def dfs(i,j,parent):
            if (i,j) in visited:
                return
            
            if i<0 or j<0 or i>=m or j>=n or grid[i][j]!=ic  :
                grid[parent[0]][parent[1]]=color
                return
            
            visited.add((i,j))
            
            dfs(i-1,j,(i,j))
            dfs(i+1,j,(i,j))
            dfs(i,j-1,(i,j))
            dfs(i,j+1,(i,j))
            
        ic=grid[row][col]
        m=len(grid)
        n=len(grid[0])
        visited=set()
        dfs(row,col,(-1,-1))
        return grid
```

```
class Solution:
    def colorBorder(self, grid: List[List[int]], row: int, col: int, color: int) -> List[List[int]]:
        rows,cols=len(grid),len(grid[0])
        g=[x.copy() for x in grid]#Create a copy of grid
        def dfs(i,j,n,visit):
            cnt=0
            for nei in [(i-1,j),(i,j+1),(i+1,j),(i,j-1)]:#Iterate neighbours
                nx,ny=nei
                if 0<=nx<rows and 0<=ny<cols and grid[nx][ny]==n:
                    cnt+=1
                    if nei not in visit:
                        visit.append(nei)
                        dfs(nx,ny,n,visit)
            if cnt!=4:#If a neighbour is not at border cnt will be 4
                g[i][j]=color
        dfs(row,col,grid[row][col],[(row,col)])
        return g
```

```
class Solution:
    def colorBorder(self, grid: List[List[int]], row: int, col: int, color: int) -> List[List[int]]:
        rows,cols=len(grid),len(grid[0])
        g=[x.copy() for x in grid]#Create a copy of grid
        def dfs(i,j,n,visit):
            cnt=0
            for nei in [(i-1,j),(i,j+1),(i+1,j),(i,j-1)]:#Iterate neighbours
                nx,ny=nei
                if 0<=nx<rows and 0<=ny<cols and grid[nx][ny]==n:
                    cnt+=1
                    if nei not in visit:
                        visit.append(nei)
                        dfs(nx,ny,n,visit)
            if cnt!=4:#If a neighbour is not at border cnt will be 4
                g[i][j]=color
        dfs(row,col,grid[row][col],[(row,col)])
        return g
```

solutions.content:
```python
def colorBorder(self, grid, r0, c0, color):
	# True if node (i, j) is inside of the connected component.
	def inside_cc(i, j):   
		# Note: Only nodes inside of the connected component are added to "visited".
		if (i, j) in visited: return True
		elif 0<=i<len(grid) and 0<=j<len(grid[0]) and grid[i][j]==cc_color:
			visited.add((i, j))
			neighbors = [(i+1, j), (i-1, j), (i, j-1), (i, j+1)]
			# If one of the neighbors is not inside of cc, then node (i, j) is a border node.
			if any([not inside_cc(x, y) for x, y in neighbors]):
				grid[i][j] = color
			return True
		else: return False
	cc_color = grid[r0][c0]
	visited = set()
	inside_cc(r0,c0)
	return grid  
```

solutions.content:
哎。。。我必须坦白这个题contest的时候没做出来，不是因为不会，而是没搞清楚border的定义被坑了，然后就一直调代码，gg。。。
这种题的思路还是很清楚的，就是漫水算法（floodfill），或者说深度优先搜索。我们可以从给定的格点开始dfs，如果发现当前点是border，就染色。
但是这里有几个坑：
1. 首先是题目关于border的描述，那个```4-directionally adjacent```的意思是只要四个邻居里面有一个和它颜色不一样就是border了，一开始还以为是4个邻居都要和它不一样。。。呜呜呜
2. 其次，我们不能直接对原数组染色，因为边dfs边染色可能影响到一些还没有搜索到的格点的条件判断，保险的做法是用另一个二维数组```should_color```来标记某个位置要不要染色

代码：
```
class Solution:
    def colorBorder(self, grid: List[List[int]], r0: int, c0: int, color: int) -> List[List[int]]:
        def is_border(grid, i, j):
			# 数组边界
            if i == 0 or i == nr - 1 or j == 0 or j == nc - 1:
                return True
			# 四个方向有一个不一样的邻居	
            target = grid[i][j]
            left = grid[i][j-1]
            right = grid[i][j+1]
            top = grid[i-1][j]
            down = grid[i+1][j]
            if left != target or right != target or top != target or down != target:
                return True
            return False
            
        def dfs(grid, i, j, target, visited, color):
			# 搜到了边界，返回
            if i < 0  or i >= nr or j < 0 or j >= nc:
                return
			# 已经搜过，返回
            if visited[i][j]:
                return
			# 当前颜色不是target的颜色，不属于这个connected component，返回
            if target != grid[i][j]:
                return
            visited[i][j] = 1
            
            if is_border(grid, i, j):
                # grid[i][j] = color  # dont do that!
                should_color[i][j] = 1
            dfs(grid, i, j+1, target, visited, color)
            dfs(grid, i, j-1, target, visited, color)
            dfs(grid, i-1, j, target, visited, color)
            dfs(grid, i+1, j, target, visited, color)
        
        nr = len(grid)
        nc = len(grid[0])
        visited = [[0]*nc for _ in range(nr)]
        should_color = [[0]*nc for _ in range(nr)]
        
        dfs(grid, r0, c0, grid[r0][c0], visited, color)
        
        for i in range(nr):
            for j in range(nc):
                if should_color[i][j]:
                    grid[i][j] = color
        
        return grid
```

```
    def colorBorder(self, grid, r0, c0, color):
        queue = deque()
		queue.append((r0,c0))
        visited = set()
        visited.add((r0,c0))
        marked = []
        direc = [(-1,0), (1,0), (0,1),(0,-1)]
        old = grid[r0][c0]
        while queue:
            r, c = queue.popleft()
            if r == 0 or r == len(grid)-1 or c == 0 or c == len(grid[0])-1 or grid[r-1][c] != old or grid[r+1][c] != old or grid[r][c-1] != old or grid[r][c+1] != old:
                marked.append((r,c))
            for d_x,d_y in direc:
                x = r+d_x
                y = c+d_y
                if x >= 0 and x < len(grid) and y >=0 and y < len(grid[0]) and grid[x][y] == old and (x,y) not in visited:
                    visited.add((x,y))
                    queue.append((x,y))
        for x,y in marked:
            grid[x][y] = color
        return grid
```

```
        visited = set()
        visited.add((r0,c0))
        marked = []
        direc = [(-1,0), (1,0), (0,1),(0,-1)]
        old = grid[r0][c0]
        while queue:
            r, c = queue.popleft()
            if r == 0 or r == len(grid)-1 or c == 0 or c == len(grid[0])-1 or grid[r-1][c] != old or grid[r+1][c] != old or grid[r][c-1] != old or grid[r][c+1] != old:
                marked.append((r,c))
            for d_x,d_y in direc:
                x = r+d_x
                y = c+d_y
                if x >= 0 and x < len(grid) and y >=0 and y < len(grid[0]) and grid[x][y] == old and (x,y) not in visited:
                    visited.add((x,y))
                    queue.append((x,y))
        for x,y in marked:
            grid[x][y] = color
        return grid
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(n+v) where v is the linear operation for checking visited list and n is for checking through n points.
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: O(n) for a visited list
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def colorBorder(self, grid: List[List[int]], row: int, col: int, color: int) -> List[List[int]]:

        rows, cols = len(grid), len(grid[0])
        visited = set()
        prev_color = grid[row][col]

        def dfs(row, col):
            # addind the node in visited
            visited.add((row, col))

            # explore four adjucent node
            for dr, dc in [(1, 0), (0, 1), (-1, 0), (0, -1)]:
                new_row, new_col = row + dr, col + dc

                # check if the new node is already visited or not
                if (new_row, new_col) not in visited:

                    # check if the new node is out of range or not
                    if (0 <= new_row < rows) and (0 <= new_col < cols):

                        # check if the new node has the same color or not
                        if grid[new_row][new_col]==prev_color:

                                # do dfs on new node
                                dfs(new_row, new_col)
                        
                        # If the node is not same color then it is a border node. Change the color        
                        else:
                            grid[row][col] = color
                    
                    # if new node out of range, then it is a border node. Change the color
                    else:
                        grid[row][col] = color
    
        # start the bfs from the given point
        dfs(row, col)

        
        return grid
```

solutions.title: python-solution-bfs
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
Applying Breadth First Search. The idea is we will take a point and then we will find out if this point is our point of interest. After that, we will look points which is 'one' distance from the first point. We can say this layer 1. In our case, there are total four points as such. Top, bottom, right and left points of the main point. We will check the top point and see if it is desired point or not. Then checke the bottom then right and then left. Layer 1 is complete. Then we will go for layer 2. We will check the 4 neighbors of Top point. And it continues.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Maintain a list called components to list down the points that needs to be checked sequntially. And then apply checking on the points from the component list.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: Although it looks like a $$O(n^3)$$ [while loop for components, inside for loop for neighbors, inside checking the neighbors in visited set] but really the computation is way less. because the for loop only checks four neighbour so instead of $$O(n * n * n)$$ it becomes $$O(n * 4 * n)$$ which is $$O(n^2)$$
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: $$O(n)$$ 
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
Correct me if I am wrong.

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def colorBorder(self, grid: List[List[int]], row: int, col: int, color: int) -> List[List[int]]:
        rows, cols = len(grid), len(grid[0])
        # co-ordinate that we visited
        visited = set()
        # co-ordinates that we need to visit
        components = [(row, col)]
        prev_color = grid[row][col]

        def bfs(row, col):
            visited.add((row, col))

            # checking four neighbors of the point
            for dr, dc in [(1, 0), (0, 1), (-1, 0), (0, -1)]:
                new_row, new_col = row + dr, col + dc
                if (new_row, new_col) not in visited:
                    if (0<=new_row<rows) and (0<=new_col<cols):
                        # add to the components if the neighboring point is not in perimeter of the matrix
                        components.append((new_row, new_col))
                        if grid[new_row][new_col] != prev_color:
                            # if the color doesn't match, means the new point is not connected component. so we don't need to visit this point anymore.
                            components.pop(-1)
                            # because colors doesn't match that means this is a border
                            grid[row][col] = color

                    else:
                        # permimeter of the matrix, border by definition
                        grid[row][col] = color

        # looping through components and do bfs for each point
        i = 0
        while i < len(components):
            bfs(*components[i])
            i += 1

        return grid

        
```

solutions.content:
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
# BFS
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Code
```
class Solution {
public:

    int dr[4]={1,0,-1,0};
    int dc[4]={0,1,0,-1};

    bool isvalid(int i ,int j,int m,int n,vector<vector<int>>& grid,int b){
        return (i >= 0 && j >= 0 && i < m && j < n && grid[i][j]==b);

    }

    vector<vector<int>> colorBorder(vector<vector<int>>& grid, int row, int col, int color) {
        int m = grid.size();
        int n = grid[0].size();
        int t = grid[row][col];

        queue<pair<int,int>> q;
        vector<vector<int>> visited(m,vector<int> (n,0));
        vector<vector<int>> newgrid;

        newgrid=grid;
        q.push({row,col});
        visited[row][col]=1;

        while(!q.empty()){
            int r=q.front().first;
            int c=q.front().second;
            q.pop();
            for(int k=0;k<4;k++){
                int nr = r+dr[k];
                int nc = c+dc[k];
                if(isvalid(nr,nc,m,n,grid,t)){
                    if(nr >= 0 && nc >= 0 && nr < m && nc < n && !visited[nr][nc]){
                        visited[nr][nc]=1;
                        q.push({nr,nc});
                    }
                }else{
                    newgrid[r][c]=color;
                }
            }
        }

        return newgrid;
    }
};
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def colorBorder(self, grid: List[List[int]], row: int, col: int, color: int) -> List[List[int]]:
        
        m, n = len(grid), len(grid[0])
        queue = [(row, col)]
        border = []
        seen = set()
        
        while queue:
            nq = []
            for r, c in queue:
                if (r,c) not in seen:
                    seen.add((r,c))
                    num = 0
                    for i, j in ((r-1,c),(r+1,c),(r,c-1),(r,c+1)):
                        if 0 <= i < m and 0 <= j < n and grid[i][j] == grid[row][col]:
                            nq.append((i,j))
                            num += 1
                    if num != 4: border.append((r,c))
            queue = nq
        
        for r, c in border: grid[r][c] = color
        return grid
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
    #在指定位置处进行dfs, 满足border条件的进行color
    #因为color后会影响判断border，所以分2步
    #1.满足border条件的添加到lst中
    #2.对lst中的进行color

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution(object):
    def colorBorder(self, grid, row, col, color):
        """
        :type grid: List[List[int]]
        :type row: int
        :type col: int
        :type color: int
        :rtype: List[List[int]]
        """
        #在指定位置处进行dfs, 满足border条件的进行color
        #因为color后会影响判断border，所以分2步
        #1.满足border条件的添加到lst中
        #2.对lst中的进行color
        m,n = len(grid),len(grid[0])
        visited = [[0 for j in range(n)] for i in range(m)]
        target = grid[row][col]
        lst = []

        def dfs(i,j):
            if 0<=i<=m-1 and 0<=j<=n-1 and visited[i][j] == 0:
                visited[i][j] = 1
                if grid[i][j] == target:
                    #上方无
                    flag = False
                    if i-1<0 or grid[i-1][j] != target:
                        flag = True
                    if i+1>m-1 or grid[i+1][j] != target:
                        flag = True
                    if j-1<0 or grid[i][j-1] != target:
                        flag = True
                    if j+1>n-1 or grid[i][j+1] != target:
                        flag = True
                    if flag:
                        lst.append((i,j))

                    dfs(i-1,j)
                    dfs(i+1,j)
                    dfs(i,j-1)
                    dfs(i,j+1)

        dfs(row,col)
        for i,j in lst:
            grid[i][j] = color
        return grid
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
# @param {Integer[][]} grid
# @param {Integer} row
# @param {Integer} col
# @param {Integer} color
# @return {Integer[][]}
def color_border(grid, row, col, color)
   @main_color = grid[row][col]
   @output = Array.new(grid.size){Array.new(grid[0].size)}
   for i in 0..grid.size - 1
        for j in 0..grid[0].size - 1
            @output[i][j] = grid[i][j]
        end
    end
   visited = Array.new(grid.size){Array.new(grid[0].size)}
   dfs([row, col], grid, visited, color)
   @output
end


def neighbours(location, row_length, col_length)
    nb = []
    nb << [location[0]+1, location[1]] if location[0] + 1 < row_length
    nb << [location[0]-1, location[1]] if location[0] > 0
    nb << [location[0], location[1]+1] if location[1] + 1 < col_length
    nb << [location[0], location[1]-1] if location[1] > 0
    nb
end

def dfs(loc, grid, visited, color)
    visited[loc[0]][loc[1]] = true
    nbrs = neighbours(loc, grid.size, grid[0].size)

    if (loc[0] == 0 || loc[0] == grid.size - 1) || (loc[1] == 0 || loc[1] == grid[0].size - 1)
        @output[loc[0]][loc[1]] = color
    else
        for nb in nbrs
            if @main_color != grid[nb[0]][nb[1]]            
                @output[loc[0]][loc[1]] = color
                break
            end
        end
    end

    for nb in nbrs
        if @main_color == grid[nb[0]][nb[1]] && !visited[nb[0]][nb[1]]
            dfs([nb[0],nb[1]], grid, visited, color)
        end
    end

end
```

```
def color_border(grid, row, col, color)

   for i in 0..grid.size - 1
        for j in 0..grid[0].size - 1
            @output[i][j] = grid[i][j]
        end
    end
   visited = Array.new(grid.size){Array.new(grid[0].size)}
   dfs([row, col], grid, visited, color)
   @output
end


def neighbours(location, row_length, col_length)
    nb = []
    nb << [location[0]+1, location[1]] if location[0] + 1 < row_length
    nb << [location[0]-1, location[1]] if location[0] > 0
    nb << [location[0], location[1]+1] if location[1] + 1 < col_length
    nb << [location[0], location[1]-1] if location[1] > 0
    nb
end

def dfs(loc, grid, visited, color)
    visited[loc[0]][loc[1]] = true
    nbrs = neighbours(loc, grid.size, grid[0].size)

    if (loc[0] == 0 || loc[0] == grid.size - 1) || (loc[1] == 0 || loc[1] == grid[0].size - 1)
        @output[loc[0]][loc[1]] = color
    else
        for nb in nbrs
            if @main_color != grid[nb[0]][nb[1]]            
                @output[loc[0]][loc[1]] = color
                break
            end
        end
    end

    for nb in nbrs
        if @main_color == grid[nb[0]][nb[1]] && !visited[nb[0]][nb[1]]
            dfs([nb[0],nb[1]], grid, visited, color)
        end
    end

end
```

```
                visited.add((x, y))

                    if (0 <= x1 < m) and (0 <= y1 < n) and ((x1, y1) not in visited) and grid[x1][y1] == color:
                        s.append((x1, y1))
            return visited

        cluster = get_component(row, col, grid[row][col])
        res = grid.copy()

                res[r][c] = color

class Solution:
    def colorBorder(self, grid: List[List[int]], row: int, col: int, color: int) -> List[List[int]]:
        
        """
        recursive format
        """
        # step-0 prep
        m, n = len(grid), len(grid[0])
        
        # step-1 dfs helper fn in recursion
        visited = set()
        # @cache
        def traverse(r, c, color):
            if r < 0 or r >= m or c < 0 or c >= n:
                return
            if grid[r][c] == color and (r, c) not in visited:
                visited.add((r, c))
                traverse(r-1, c, color)
                traverse(r+1, c, color)
                traverse(r, c-1, color)
                traverse(r, c+1, color)
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
We can use BFS solution to solve this problem. Start from point (row, col) and move to the neighbors if neighbour has color that we should repaint. We should use visited and painted set to define visited and painted points.

# Approach
Define a queue and first point in the queue as grid[row][col].
Use BFS to move to the neigbours of current point if the neigbour has color that should be repainted. If all neigbours should be repainted or were repainted that current point should be leave with current color because the current point in the middle. Otherwise, repaint current point and add the point to repainted.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
$$O(m*n)$$

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def colorBorder(self, grid: List[List[int]], row: int, col: int, color: int) -> List[List[int]]:
        m = len(grid)
        if m == 0:
            return grid
        n = len(grid[0])

        dr = [[-1,0],[0,1],[1,0],[0,-1]]
        visited = set()
        painted = set()
        cl = grid[row][col]

        q = deque()
        q.append([row, col])
        while q:
            for i in range(len(q)):
                paint = False
                y, x = q.popleft()
                key = str(y) + ':' + str(x)
                if key in visited:
                    continue
                visited.add(key)
                for dY, dX in dr:
                    newY = y + dY
                    newX = x + dX
                    if newY >= 0 and newY < m and newX >= 0 and newX < n and grid[newY][newX] == cl:
                        q.append([newY, newX])
                    elif str(newY) + ':' + str(newX) not in painted:
                        paint = True
                if paint:
                    painted.add(key)
                    grid[y][x] = color
        return grid
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
Starting from the given cell (row, col) traverse all the neighbors (UP, DOWN, RIGHT, LEFT neighbors) with the same color, and change the cell's color to given color. But we should only change the color of cell when it is a border.

A cell can be a border in 2 cases only:
- 1. when it is already in the border of the grid
- 2. when it is in the middle of the grid and one of the neighbor has different color

We can solve this problem with either DFS or BFS.
For both of them the approach, intuition, complexity analysis are the same.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
1. starting from the given cell (row, col)
2. mark this cell as visited
3. traverse all neighbors [(1,0), (-1, 0), (0,1), (0,-1)] with the same color only
4. if one of the neighbors has different color mark `isBorder` flag as true
5. if the current cell is border change its color

 
# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(MN)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: O(MN)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code

**DFS (Iteratative Approach)**
```
class Solution:
    def colorBorder(self, grid: List[List[int]], r: int, c: int, new_color: int) -> List[List[int]]:
        R, C = len(grid), len(grid[0])
        visited = set()
        queue = deque([(r, c)])
        neighbor = [(1,0), (-1,0), (0,1), (0,-1)]
        color = grid[r][c]

        while queue:
            row, col = queue.popleft()
            visited.add((row, col))
            isBorder = False

            for r, c in neighbor:
                new_r, new_c = row + r, col+c

                # skip when the neighbor cell (new_r, new_c) is out of bound or already visited
                if new_r < 0 or new_r >= R or new_c < 0 or new_c >= C or (new_r, new_c) in visited:
                    continue

                # mark current cell (row, col) as border, when neighbor cell (new_r, new_c) has a different color
                if grid[new_r][new_c] != color:
                    isBorder = True
                    continue

                queue.append((new_r, new_c))
            # if the current (row, col) is already the border of the grid, color the cell with new_color
            # if isBorder is true, color the cell with new_color
            if row == 0 or row == R-1 or col == 0 or col == C-1 or isBorder:
                grid[row][col] = new_color

        return grid
```

**DFS Approach with recursion**
```

    def colorBorder(self, grid: List[List[int]], r: int, c: int, new_color: int) -> List[List[int]]:
        R, C = len(grid), len(grid[0])
        visited = set()

        def dfs(row, col, color):
            visited.add((row, col))
            neighbor = [(1,0), (-1,0), (0,1), (0,-1)]

            isBorder = False

            for r, c in neighbor:
                new_r, new_c = row+r, col+c
                
                if new_r < 0 or new_r >= R or new_c < 0 or new_c >= C or (new_r, new_c) in visited:
                    continue

                if grid[new_r][new_c] != color:
                    isBorder = True
                    continue

                dfs(new_r, new_c, color)
            
            if row == 0 or row == R-1 or col == 0 or col == C-1 or isBorder:
                grid[row][col] = new_color

        dfs(r, c, grid[r][c])

        return grid
```

**BFS Approach**

```
            # if isBorder is true, color the cell with new_color

                grid[row][col] = new_color

        return grid
```

solutions.content:
# Python, DFS:
##### We can color the border inside the DFS.

```
class Solution:
    def colorBorder(self, grid, r0, c0, color):
        seen, m, n = set(), len(grid), len(grid[0])
        def dfs(x, y):
            if (x, y) in seen: return True
            if not (0 <= x < m and 0 <= y < n and grid[x][y] == grid[r0][c0]): return False
            seen.add((x, y))
            if dfs(x + 1, y) + dfs(x - 1, y) + dfs(x, y + 1) + dfs(x, y - 1) < 4: grid[x][y] = color
            return True
        dfs(r0, c0)
        return grid
```

# Python, BFS:

```
    def colorBorder(self, grid, r0, c0, color):
        m, n = len(grid), len(grid[0])
        bfs, component, border = [[r0, c0]], set([(r0, c0)]), set()
        for r0, c0 in bfs:
            for i, j in [[0, 1], [1, 0], [-1, 0], [0, -1]]:
                r, c = r0 + i, c0 + j
                if 0 <= r < m and 0 <= c < n and grid[r][c] == grid[r0][c0]:
                    if (r, c) not in component:
                        bfs.append([r, c])
                        component.add((r, c))
                else: border.add((r0, c0))
        for x, y in border: grid[x][y] = color
        return grid
```

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def colorBorder(self, grid: List[List[int]], row: int, col: int, color: int) -> List[List[int]]:

        visited, changed = set(), set()
        stack = deque()
        
        color_initial = grid[row][col]
        row_n, col_n  = len(grid), len(grid[0])
        
        # add initial cell to stack
        stack.append([row, col])
        while stack:
            r, c = stack.pop()
            if (r, c) in visited:   continue
            visited.add((r, c))

            ind_brd = False   # indicator of border 
            for r_dlt, c_dlt in [[-1, 0], [0, -1], [1, 0], [0, 1]]:
                if 0 <= r + r_dlt < row_n and \
                   0 <= c + c_dlt < col_n: 
                    
                    new_cell = grid[r + r_dlt][c + c_dlt]

                    # cell on boundary of the grid     or
                    # adjacent cell has another color  --> ind = True
                    if r in (0, row_n - 1) or \
                       c in (0, col_n - 1) or  new_cell != color_initial:
                        ind_brd = True
                    
                    # cell has the same color --> add to stack 
                    if new_cell == color_initial:
                        stack.append([r + r_dlt, c + c_dlt])

            # we should change color in the end, otherwise we could paint cells inside              
            # add cell to the set
            if ind_brd:
                changed.add((r, c))
        
        # paint borders
        for (r, c) in changed:
            grid[r][c] = color

        return grid



```

The border of a connected component is all the squares in the connected component that are either 4-directionally adjacent to a square not in the component, or on the boundary of the grid (the first or last row or column).

What is this english lmao? Total BS.

the border of a connected component is all the squares in the connected component that are 4-directionally adjacent to a square not in the component. How is this possible?
It is connected and are 4-directionally adjacent to a square not in the component at the same time?

***The border of a connected component is all the squares in the connected component that are either 4-directionally adjacent to a square not in the component, or on the boundary of the grid (the first or last row or column).***

Border of connect component means all the cell which has src color in a connected component ( in our diagram it is 2 ) which are not 4 directionally connected with the src color

title: Minimum Possible Integer After at Most K Adjacent Swaps On Digits
question_content:
You are given a string num representing the digits of a very large integer and an integer k. You are allowed to swap any two adjacent digits of the integer at most k times.

Return the minimum integer you can obtain also as a string.

 

Example 1:

Input: num = "4321", k = 4
Output: "1342"
Explanation: The steps to obtain the minimum integer from 4321 with 4 adjacent swaps are shown.

Example 2:

Input: num = "100", k = 1
Output: "010"
Explanation: It's ok for the output to have leading zeros, but the input is guaranteed not to have any leading zeros.

Example 3:

Input: num = "36789", k = 1000
Output: "36789"
Explanation: We can keep the number without any swaps.

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= num.length <= 3 * 104
  • num consists of only digits and does not contain leading zeros.
  • 1 <= k <= 109

solutions.title: o-n-logn-detailed-explanation
the-constraint-was-not-very-helpful-c-python-clean-56ms-o-n2-solution
python-17-lines-o-nlogn-solution
solutions.content:
The idea is quite straightforward: 
`In each round, pick the smallest number within k distance and move it to the front.`
For each number, we save its indexes in a deque.
In each round, we check from 0 to 9 to see if the nearest index is within k distance.
But here comes the tricky part:
`The index of a number may change due to the swaps we made in the previous rounds.`
For example, if 3 numbers after `num[i]` are moved to the front,
then the index of `num[i]` becomes `i + 3` in the new array.
So we need a data structure to store the indexes of picked numbers,
to support fast calculation of the new index of each remaining number.
BIT, Segment Tree and Balanced Binary Search Tree can do this.
Here I use `sortedcontainers`, which is an implementation of Balanced Binary Search Tree.

```
from collections import defaultdict, deque
from sortedcontainers import SortedList
from string import digits
class Solution:
    def minInteger(self, num: str, k: int) -> str:
        d = defaultdict(deque)
        for i, a in enumerate(num):
            d[a].append(i)
        ans, seen = '', SortedList()
        for _ in range(len(num)):
            for a in digits:
                if d[a]:
                    i = d[a][0]
                    ni = i + (len(seen) - seen.bisect(i))
                    dis = ni - len(seen)
                    if dis <= k:
                        k -= dis
                        d[a].popleft()
                        ans += a
                        seen.add(i)
                        break
        return ans
```

```
    def minInteger(self, num: str, k: int) -> str:
        d = defaultdict(deque)
        for i, a in enumerate(num):
            d[a].append(i)
        ans, seen = '', SortedList()
        for _ in range(len(num)):
            for a in digits:
                if d[a]:
                    i = d[a][0]
                    ni = i + (len(seen) - seen.bisect(i))
                    dis = ni - len(seen)
                    if dis <= k:
                        k -= dis
                        d[a].popleft()
                        ans += a
                        seen.add(i)
                        break
        return ans
```

solutions.content:
**Idea**
Greedily select the smallest number we can reach, and push it all the way to the front.

**Complexity**
- time: O(n^2)
- space: O(n)

**Python**
```
class Solution:
    def minInteger(self, num: str, k: int) -> str:
        num = [*map(int, num)]
        if k >= (len(num) ** 2) // 2:
            return ''.join(map(str, sorted(num)))
        
        res = []
        q = [(v, i) for i, v in enumerate(num)]
        while k and q:
            idx, (v, i) = min(enumerate(q[:k + 1]), key=lambda p:p[1])
            k -= idx
            del q[idx]
            res += v,
            
        res += [v for v, _ in q]
        return ''.join(map(str, res))
```

solutions.content:
A greedy approach will do the job.
Iterate the index i from the left to right. Each iteration do a swap in a greedy way, i.e. swap num[i] with the smallest number within num[i+1:]

```
class Solution:
    ''' greedy approach. start from the left side, 
	    and everytime pick the smallest number on the right side that is able to swap, then do the swap
    '''
    def minInteger(self, num: str, k: int) -> str:
        min_num = sorted(list(num))
        min_num = ''.join(min_num)
        i = 0
        to_find = 0
        while num != min_num and k > 0 and i < len(num):
            indx = num.find(str(to_find), i)
            while indx != -1:
                if indx - i <= k:   # able to swap
                    num = num[:i] + num[indx] + num[i:indx] + num[indx+1:]  # the swap
                    k -= (indx - i)
                    i += 1
                    to_find = 0     # restart the to_find variable
                    indx = num.find(str(to_find), i)
                else:
                    break
            to_find += 1
        return num
```

python-o-n-10-deques-with-1-stack
solutions.content:
# Idea

The first digit of the output should be the minimum of the first `k + 1` digits in `num`, i.e., `min(num[:k+1])`. Similarly, the `i`-th digit of the output should be `min(num[i:i+k+1])`, where we assume
* The digits of `num` are swapped in-place. That is, `num[:i]` are already the first `i` digits of the output.
* `k` is the remaining number of moves, which decreases as more and more digits are swapped.

If we swap digits one by one, we will end up with a `O(n^2)` algorithm because there will be a maximum of `O(n^2)` swaps needed. Therefore, we need a more efficient way to swap the digits.

Instead of actually swapping *adjacent* digits, assume we store all the digits of interest (`num[i:i+k+1]`) as a **sequence** in a data structure `D`, which supports the following 4 operations:
1. `push(x)`: Push `x` to the end of `D`.
2. `pop()`: Pop the last element of `D`.
3. `pop_min()`: Pop the minimum digit in `D`. If there are multiple ones, return the first one.
4. `get_min_position()`: Get the position of the minimum digit in `D`. Here the *position* is the 0-based index in the sequence.

Then, we can solve the problem this way.

```py
def minInteger(self, num: str, k: int) -> str:
    data = D()   # Empty sequence
    output = ''  # Output string
    for i in range(len(num)):
	    # Make sure data contains the (k + 1) digits of interest
	    while data.count < k + 1:
		    x = next_digit_in_num()
		    data.push(x)
		while data.count > k + 1:
		    data.pop()
		# data.get_min_position() is the number of swaps to move the minimum digit to
		# the desired position (output[i])
		k -= data.get_min_position()
		# Find the minimum number in data
		x = data.pop_min()
		# x is the i-th digit of output
		output += x
	return output
```

By `next_digit_in_num()`, we mean to find the first digit in `num` which is neither in `output` nor `data`.

# Achieving O(n)

The remaining question is how to implement `D` efficiently. It's easier to explain with an example. Suppose in some iteration `data` contains `[1, 0, 2, 1, 0]`. We store 2 attributes for each element `x` in `data`:
* `x.index`: The index of `x` in the input string `num`.
* `x.moves`: The number of elements preceding `x` in `data` that are **greater than** `x`. It will become clear later why this is called *moves*.

Since there are only 10 possible digits (`0` to `9`), we can store these elements in 10 lists, one per digit:
```py
# The tuples stand for (index, moves)
digits[0] = [(1, 1), (4, 3)]
digits[1] = [(0, 0), (3, 1)]
digits[2] = [(2, 0)]
...
```

This way, all the 4 operations of `D` can be done in `O(1)` time.
1. `push(x)`: To calculate `x.moves`, we only need to count the total number of elements in `digits[x+1]`, ..., `digits[9]`. Then, simply append `x` as well as its index to `digits[x]`.
2. `pop()`: Compare the last element of `digits[x]` for `x in range(10)` and pop the one with minimum index.
3. `pop_min()`: Find the minimum `x` with non-empty `digits[x]` and remove the first element of `digits[x]`. **Note that we don't need to update any `moves` attributes of the remaining elements in `data`**, because all the elements after `x` should be greater than or equal to `x`.
4. `get_min_position()`: Find the minimum `x` with non-empty `digits[x]`, and return `x.moves`. **`x.moves` will be exactly its position in the sequence** because all the elements preceding `x` should be greater than `x`. In other words, `x.moves` is the **number of moves** required to swap `x` all the way to the front of the sequence.

# Complete code

```py
from collections import deque, namedtuple

Digit = namedtuple('Digit', ['index', 'moves'])

class Solution:
    def minInteger(self, num: str, k: int) -> str:
        n = len(num)
        remain_num = [(i, ord(x) - ord('0')) for i, x in enumerate(num)][::-1]
        digits = [deque() for _ in range(10)]
        count = 0   # Number of elements in digits
        output = []
        for _ in range(n):
            # Ensure digits has (k + 1) elements (unless insufficient)
            while remain_num and count < k + 1:
                index, x = remain_num.pop()
                # moves: Number of elements before x that are greater than x
                moves = sum(map(len, digits[x+1:]))    
                digits[x].append(Digit(index, moves))
                count += 1
            while count > k + 1:
                # Find digit with maximum index
                d = max((digit[-1], i) for i, digit in enumerate(digits) if digit)[1]
                x = digits[d].pop()
                remain_num.append((x.index, d))
                count -= 1
            # Find the minimum element in the list
            d = min(i for i, digit in enumerate(digits) if digit)
            x = digits[d].popleft()
            count -= 1
            k -= x.moves
            output.append(d)
        return ''.join(chr(ord('0') + d) for d in output)
```

# Analysis of time complexity

Let `r1[i]` and `r2[i]` be the number of iterations of the first and second while loop, in the `i`-th iteration of the for loop. We will show that `sum(r1) + sum(r2) = O(n)`, where `n` is the length of the input string `num`.

In the first iteration of the for loop (`i = 0`), since `k >= 1`, `r1[0] = k + 1` and `r2[0] = 0`.

To find the upper bound of `r1[i]` and `r2[i]` for `i > 0`, we need to define some terms first. Let `T0[i]` be the moment right before entering the `i`-th iteration of the for loop, and `T1[i]` be the moment at the end of the `i`-th iteration. We use `k[i]` to denote the value of `k` in the code at `T0[i]`, and similarly `count[i]` for the value of `count` at `T0[i]`.

Now assume `i > 0`. Observe that if `count[i] <= k[i] - 1`, then `count` must be no greater than `k` *right before `digits[d].popleft()` is called in the previous iteration*, which means that `remain_num` must be empty in previous iteration, and hence in `T0[i]`. This observation shows that we either have `count[i] >= k[i]` or `remain_num` is empty in `T0[i]`, which proves that `r1[i] <= 1` for all `i > 0`. Therefore, `sum(r1) <= n`.

In `T1[i-1]`, it's clear that `count <= k` (because of the `count -= 1`), which is equivalent to `count[i] <= k[i-1]`. As a result,
```py
(*)  r2[i] <= count - (k[i] + 1)
           <= k[i-1] - (k[i] + 1)
```

Now we claim that `sum(r2) <= 2n`. Let `j` be the minimum `i` with `k[i] < n - 1`. If such `i` doesn't exist, then `r2[i] = 0` for all `i > 0` (because `count` is always at most `n`) and we're done. Otherwise, by `(*)`,
```py
sum(r2[j+1:n]) <= k[j] - k[n-1] - 1 <= k[j] <= n
```
Combining all the results,
```py
sum(r2) = r2[0] + sum(r2[0:j]) + r2[j] + sum(r2[j+1:n])
        = r2[j] + sum(r2[j+1:n])
        <= n + n
```
which proves the claim.

solutions.content:
The `O(N*logN)` solution requires a bit of leap of faith and view the problem from a different angle. I've also left in my first attempt that TLEs which would give some motivation to the `O(N*logN)`
solution.

The key to understanding the solution is viewing it as a selection problem instead of a swapping problem. You have n position to fill with the best digit possible, from n candidate digits. For each position i, you have n - i candidate digits to choose from such that the digit chosen must not be too far away from index i. 

```
from sortedcontainers import SortedList

class Solution:
    # O(N*LogN) solution
    def minInteger(self, num: str, k: int) -> str:            
        smaller_digit_indexes = collections.defaultdict(collections.deque)
        A = [int(d) for d in num]
        for i in range(len(A)):
            smaller_digit_indexes[A[i]].append(i)
        
        result = ''
        pulled_to_front_indexes = SortedList()
        # This problem requires a leap of faith. Instead of thinking how we could replace
        # each individual digit at index i by swapping, let's view it as a selecting problem
        # where we continously try to select the smallest digit possible, from all that are
        # available, and add them into a result list.
        n = len(A)
        for _ in range(n):
            # Given n digits that are available for selection, we've so far selected len(result)
            # number of digits and is now looking for the best digit to add to result. Since
            # we want the smallest digit possible, we go through digit 0-9 (at a constant loop cost
            # of 10) and stop at the first available digit.
            for d in range(0, 10):
                if len(smaller_digit_indexes[d]) == 0:
                    continue
                
                # Okay, we have `d` that we could potentially add to result. To build some intuition,
                # let's forget about all the swapping business and simply imagine we've so far pulled 
				# len(result) digits out of A, each digit pulled out leaving a hole in A, and the 
                # remaining digits in A remains in-place in their original index. And, `d`, the potential 
                # candidate for selection is at A[j]. In other words, in each iteration of the loop
                # (from 0 to n - 1), we are looking to see if the first digit in those that remain in A
                # could be replaced by `d` at A[j]. If so, we simply pull `d` out of its position at j
                # and place it into `result`.
                j = smaller_digit_indexes[d][0]
                
                # Now the question is, could we possibly choose `d` at its original index j given the
                # constraint that we cannot touch digits that are more than k digits away? (Here k
                # digits away means number of digits between some start and some end, inclusive, minus 1)
                # Well we could if the number of digits from `d` at the j original index j, to the 
                # first digit remaining in A that we've not yet pulled out (and put into `result`) is <= k.
                # Why? Because if you were to do the swapping process step by step, you'll notice that
                # other than digits we've pulled and put into `result`, the remaining digits
                # in A have remained in the same relative order, except for the holes. We only need to
                # deduct for the holes they are between the first digit of A and j, to arrive at the 
                # true distance
                nb_moved_to_front = pulled_to_front_indexes.bisect_right(j)
                dist = j - nb_moved_to_front
                if dist == 0 or dist <= k:
                    # dist == 0 means `d` happens to be the first digit remaining in A
                    result += str(d)
                    pulled_to_front_indexes.add(j)
                    smaller_digit_indexes[d].popleft()
                    k -= dist
                    break

        return result

    # First O(N^2) attempt that will LTE
    def minInteger2(self, num: str, k: int) -> str:
        def bubble_up(A, i, j):
            t = A[j]
            for x in range(j, i, -1):
                A[x] = A[x - 1]
            A[i] = t
                
            
        A = [int(d) for d in num]
        
        i = 0
        while i < len(A) and k > 0:
            # Given A[i], let's see if we can find the smallest possible A[j] such that j - i <= k.
            # That is, the smallest possible A[j], k-swap distance away that we could swap with A[i] 
            # and get a smallest possible number
            j = i + 1
            min_digit_idx = None
            while j < len(A) and j - i <= k:
                if A[j] < A[i]:
                    if min_digit_idx is None or A[j] < A[min_digit_idx]:
                        min_digit_idx = j
                j += 1
            
            if min_digit_idx != None:
                bubble_up(A, i, min_digit_idx)
                k -= min_digit_idx - i
            
            i += 1
        
        return ''.join([str(d) for d in A])
```

solutions.content:
In this post I will focus on stepping through my thought process in solving this question and only post the full solution at the end. So a word of warning: **long post**. But hopefully some may find this useful :) You can also practice implementing after reading analysis instead of refering to the full solution.

**Initial Analysis**
1) Understand the questions first, realize that *optimal is just the sorted array of digits given* and that greedily making permissible moves of smallest digit to the front will always be optimal. I.e. no movement of digits near the end of the number will yield as large a decrease as *decreasing the leading (leftmost) digit*.
2) Look for bounds, `1 <= num.length <= 30000`, and `1 <= k <= 10^9` suggests we cannot use O(k) solution and need faster than O(N^2) to AC. The bounds also give some hints to what's permissible in solution, in this case, O(N\*log(N)) will be ok. (And generally is the case except for very large bounds, hard to distinguish between O(N) vs O(N\*log(N)) solution timings - unless you're using python T.T)

**First-pass *(horribly wrong)***
- Insight 1: Index of digit determines least number of swaps needed to move it to the front
- Insight 2: Number of digits moved before will decrease this cost proportionately (wrong)
- So we can do *O(N)* scan while keeping counter for number of previously moved digits?
- Since we need to move smaller digits first, if we have a sorted list of digits by index per digit, then doing repeated greedy scans from `0` to `9` always picking from smaller digit first will give us the order of digits to move? (also actually wrong)
- That's not too bad, we can init queues for each digit type and push index of each digit as we encounter them by scanning through `num` once with O(N) time and space (number of digit types is constant) then pop them as we consider each digit O(1) time.

*code, code, code, Run, Failed!* :O

**Ofc, LC-hard, not so easy - Second Try**
- Does not pass first test case, seems like we are missing caveat from Insight 1&2. Not the case that number of digits previously moved discounts the next move proportionately, rather:
- Insight 3: Number of digits with indices smaller than current digit's index will discount number of swaps to move current digit to front
- So we have to not only keep track of how many moves-to-front we've made but at which indices we've made them from
- Naive Solution:
  - Keep list of moved digit indices
  - Scan through list when computing next move feasibility (cost) and count number of smaller indices for discount
  - O(N) scan per digit => O(N^2) overall, TLE (oops)
- Have to think of better way to store and lookup number of indices smaller than current
  - This is the actual issue in this problem

**Abstract the problem a bit -> Reduce to a familiar classic problem**
- Given a list of numbers, find how many are smaller than a given query
- We have a time-budget of O(log(N)) -> What algos do we know that can do this? BinarySearch
- Problem: BinarySearch only works when the given list of numbers are already sorted.
  - Time cost incurred to sort again: O(N\*log(N)) => TLE
- **Insight 4** (what needed to click for me to solve this):
  - Instead of thinking of *the* (single) list of previously moved digits, we know that the order in which we move a certain type of digit (say all `0`s moved so far) have strictly increasing indices!
  - In other words, we already have 10 sorted lists of previously moved indices and we can just do multiple searches for each type of digit previously moved and take the sum as total 'discount' for currently considered move.
  - If we just store a 'taken' index for which index we have already taken for this digit type and increment this each time we move a digit to the front rather than using queues, we can reuse sorted arrays for each digit type with `digit[i][:taken[i]+1]` (this store indices of previously moved digits of type `i`)
- Time analysis:
  - 10\*O(log(N)) ~ O(log(N)) => AC :) at least on time

**Yay! AC?**
- Nope...
- Failed Testcase:
  - "294984148179"
11
- Output:
  - "124499488179"
- Expected:
  - "124498948179"
- Notice that in this case, our solution chose to move the third '4' rather than the first '8' ahead by 1 position
- Stepping through algo to debug:
  - We notice that after [1244]99848179, we move 'up' (retain) '9' in what's currently at index 5, thereafter, as per our greedy strategy, we look for more digits of type '9' to move, which is in the next position, and so we end up with [124499]848179 and then restart from '0' and end up moving '4' up one position since with `k=1` left, that is the next most optimal choice we have
- Insight 5 (last one, I promise): When it is impossible to move up any digit smaller than at the current index, we need to consider moving smaller digits into the next position instead and restart from '0'
- With this last modification, our solution will restart the greedy scan from '0' after [12449]9848179 and consider moving up '8' with the last swap instead of retaining '9' and moving '4'.
- But does this restart hurt our time?
  - Each time we choose to move a digit, we reduce the number of digits we have to look at by 1
  - For each choice of digit movement, we consider moving up at most 10 digits (0-9 and only if our current digit is 9) and to compute each digit's cost, we do at most 10\*O(log(N))
  - Worst case: 100\*O(log(N)) per digit in given `num` string ~ O(N\*log(N)) time complexity, should be ok.
- AC :D

Thanks for reading, hopefully stepping through my approach was helpful to some of you!

**TL;DR:** realize we need to find how many digits we've moved prior (smaller than) current digit's index in O(log(N)) time, use BinarySearch, problem: sorted array of previously moved digits' index? No problem, we are already picking them in sorted order for each type `0-9`, just whack with 10xBinarySearch, still asymptotically overall O(N\*log(N)) solution => AC :)

**A bit lengthly solution, but with comments and debugging output to help with understanding**
```python
# Turn on for debugging output
DEBUG = False

# Generic binary search to return insertion index
def binarySearch(arr, s, t, n):
    m = (s+t)//2
    if (s == t):
        return s
    if (arr[m] > n):
        return binarySearch(arr, s, m, n)
    else:
        return binarySearch(arr, m+1, t, n)
    
class Solution:
    def __init__(self):
        self.digits = dict()
        self.taken = [-1 for i in range(10)]
    
    # Compute how much it costs to move this digit to the front
    def cost(self, cur):
        discount = 0
		# Sum previously moved digits with index less than cur for each type
        for i in range(10):
            discount += binarySearch(self.digits[i], 0, self.taken[i]+1, cur)
			
            if (DEBUG):
                if (self.taken[i] >= 0):
                    print(f"{i}: [{self.digits[i][:self.taken[i]+1]}] search:{cur} discount:{binarySearch(self.digits[i],0,self.taken[i]+1,cur)}")
        return cur - discount
    
    def minInteger(self, num: str, k: int) -> str:
        if (DEBUG):
            print(f"Testcase: [{num}] k={k}")
        
        # Keep sorted arrays (by index) for each occurance of digits
        self.digits = {i:[] for i in range(10)}
        for i,n in enumerate(num):
            self.digits[int(n)].append(i)
        
        extracted = set()
        head = "" # constructed 'front' of string
        
        # Terminating conditions:
        # 1) No more swaps left
        # 2) We have sorted our array
        while k > 0 and len(head) < len(num):
            i = 0
            # Scan each digit occurances from smalled (0) to largest (9) in order
            # to greedily make best permissible moves to front
            while i < 10:
                # Sanity check that we still have digits not yet moved to front
                while k > 0 and len(self.digits[i]) and self.taken[i]+1 < len(self.digits[i]):
                    # Get number of swaps to move current digit to front
					curCost = self.cost(self.digits[i][self.taken[i]+1])
                    
                    if (DEBUG):
                        print(f"move to head:{i}@{self.digits[i][self.taken[i]+1]} cost: {curCost}")
                    
                    # If we can move this digit, move it
                    if (curCost <= k):
                        self.taken[i] += 1
                        k -= curCost
                        extracted.add(self.digits[i][self.taken[i]])
                        head += str(i)
                        
                        if (DEBUG):
                            print(f"[{head}]",end="")
                            for j in range(len(num)):
                                if j in extracted:
                                    continue
                                print(num[j],end="")
                            print(f" k={k}")
                    # Otherwise, no further digit of this kind could possible be moved
                    # since our self.digits[i] array is sorted (move onto the next digit)
                    else:
                        break
                    # When we move a digit 'for free', we reset our search as a previously seen
                    # not-possible but more optimal (smaller) digit could now be moved to front
                    if (curCost == 0):
                        i = 0
                # remember to increment our search onto the next smallest digit
                i += 1
                
        # Parse and output final answer
        for i in range(len(num)):
            if i in extracted:
                continue
            head += num[i]
        return head
```

solutions.content:
Algo
Scan through the string. At each index, look for the smallest element behind it within k swaps. Upon finding such minimum, swap it to replece the current element, and reduce k to reflect the swaps. Do this for all element until k becomes 0. 

`O(N^2)` time & `O(N)` space 
```
class Solution:
    def minInteger(self, num: str, k: int) -> str:
        n = len(num)
        if k >= n*(n-1)//2: return "".join(sorted(num)) #special case
        
        #find smallest elements within k swaps 
        #and swap it to current position 
        num = list(num)
        for i in range(n):
            if not k: break 
            #find minimum within k swaps
            ii = i
            for j in range(i+1, min(n, i+k+1)): 
                if num[ii] > num[j]: ii = j 
            #swap the min to current position 
            if ii != i: 
                k -= ii-i
                for j in range(ii, i, -1):
                    num[j-1], num[j] = num[j], num[j-1]
        return "".join(num)
```

solutions.content:
Well.. the average performance should be NlogN, but it is hard to prove whether the worst case still holds. Anyway, I still share my solution.

```
from heapq import heapify, heappop, heappush

def getsum(tree, i): 
    s = 0
    i += 1
    while i > 0: 
        s += tree[i] 
        i -= i & (-i) 
    return s 
  
# modify the value from the original one,
# v is diff/increment.
def update(tree, i ,v): 
    i += 1
    while i < len(tree): 
        tree[i] += v 
        i += i & (-i)
        
def construct(arr): 
    tree = [0] * (len(arr) + 1) 
  
    for i in range(len(arr)): 
        update(tree, i, arr[i]) 

    return tree 

class Solution:
    def minInteger(self, num: str, k: int) -> str:
        pq = []
        ans = []
        
        # the input array looks like [0, 1,1,1,1,...]
        tree = construct([0] + [1] * len(num))
        

        used = set()
        # a heap to store un-unsed indices
        wait_queue = list(range(len(num)))
        heapify(wait_queue)
        
        
        while k > 0:
            # getsum(tree, idx) is to get the actual index of an element whose original index
            # is idx.
            while len(wait_queue) > 0 and getsum(tree, wait_queue[0]) <= len(ans) + k: 
                idx = heappop(wait_queue)
                heappush(pq, (num[idx], idx))
                
            if len(pq) == 0:
                break
            ch, i = heappop(pq)
            
            
            cost = getsum(tree, i) - len(ans)
            if cost > k:
                heappush(wait_queue, i)
                continue
                
            k -= cost
            
            # move the one from i and add to zero.
            update(tree, i + 1, -1)
            update(tree, 0, 1)    
            
            
            ans.append(ch)
            used.add(i)
            
        for i, ch in enumerate(num):
            if i not in used:
                ans.append(ch)
        
        return "".join(ans)
        
        
        
```

o-nlogn-a-sortedlist-and-10-queues
solutions.content:
# Intuition
Iterating from the left, we want to find the smallest reacheable digit and put it on each place.

# Approach
We keep 10 queues, containing sequences of indices for each digit. At each step we pick the smallest digit that is not further than `k` steps away. After that we remove it from its queue, and reduce `k` by the number of steps used.

The question, then, rises, how to recalculate the correct indices and distances after a digit is removed from its place. Of course, we don't want to modify the queues, that would be too slow. But, it can be seen that the correction to every index is simply the number of used indices to the left of it, which we can calculate efficiently with `SortedList`.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(nlogn)$$, dominated by `SortedList` operations, at most `n` inserts and `n` bisections. Technically, `SortedList` has larger [time complexity](https://grantjenks.com/docs/sortedcontainers/performance-scale.html), but in practice it is fast.

- Space complexity: $$O(n)$$, one `SortedList` and 10 queues each

# Code
```
from collections import deque
from sortedcontainers import SortedList

class Solution:
    def minInteger(self, num: str, k: int) -> str:
        N = len(num)
        lists = [deque() for _ in range(10)]
        for i,c in enumerate(num):
            lists[int(c)].append(i)
        res = []
        used = SortedList()
        unused = set(range(N))
        while k and len(res) < N:
            for d in range(10):
                if not lists[d]:
                    continue
                i = lists[d][0]
                i -= used.bisect_left(i)
                if i <= k:
                    k -= i
                    i = lists[d].popleft()
                    used.add(i)
                    unused.remove(i)
                    res.append(i)
                    break
        res.extend(unused)
        return ''.join(num[x] for x in res)

```

solutions.title: python-sliding-window-avl-tree-solution-easy-to-understand
solutions.content:
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Maintain a window of size ```k``` in a AVL Tree, pop out the minimum element in the index in $$O(log(n))$$ time, find its index, decrement ```k``` accordingly until ```k``` becomes ```0```.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(n * log(n))$$
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: $$O(n)$$
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```python []
from sortedcontainers import SortedList

class Solution:
    def minInteger(self, num: str, k: int) -> str:
        sz, window = len(num), SortedList()
        remainedIndices, poppedIndices = SortedList(range(sz)), []
        while k > 0:
            while len(window) < k + 1 and len(window) < len(remainedIndices):
                idx = remainedIndices[len(window)]
                window.add((num[idx], idx))
            if not window:
                break
            index = window.pop(0)[1]
            k -= remainedIndices.bisect_left(index)
            remainedIndices.remove(index)
            poppedIndices.append(index)
            for idx in remainedIndices[k + 1: len(window)]:
                window.remove((num[idx], idx))
        poppedSet = set(poppedIndices)
        return "".join(num[idx] for idx in poppedIndices) + "".join(num[idx] for idx in range(sz) if idx not in poppedSet)
```
